Phys Rep: 70 word spell in spellbook Arcane Focus. 5” minimum red spellball or alternatively character themed coreless red throwing weapons such as darts, knives, or axes.

Description: The Mage’s continued study in the necromantic arts allows them to increase the strength of their undead minions. The Mage may now create their Skeleton or Zombie as a Knight, which triples their undead HP and allows them to speak and follow more advanced commands. The Knight may also use Mighty Blow (Warrior Skill, Tier 4) a single time if they wield a two handed weapon. When players regain life, they do not regain any memories of their actions while animated.
Special: 10 minutes or until slain. If not slain within 10 minutes, the undead player may choose to remain an undead minion to the casting Mage for only as long as they wish.
Limitations: Players may decline to be animated. A Mage may only have 1 Undead Knight in play per 3 Mage/Healer Tiers.
Phys Rep: 100 word spell in spellbook, and roleplay. Gray headband with two black skulls or an even meaner skeleton mask.

Description: The Mage conjures an NPC creature to do their bidding. The NPC summoned will be based on the adventure setting and at the discretion of Game Officials. Alternatively, a Unit or Faction may create a creature concept and have that monster be played by a teammate with Game Officials approval.
Limitations: Requires coordination with the Game Officials. Cannot be used in conjunction with Spell Storing.
Phys Rep: 100 word spell in spellbook, Arcane Focus. Green ribbon tied to the weapon or item.

Description: The Mage is able to use any weapon of their choice as their Arcane Focus. The Mage may now take damage from a single, mundane stroke without interrupting their casting. The Mage may now cast without referencing their spellbook; spells subsequently must be memorized. The Mage may use their Ensorcelled Armament to cast Combat Magic via touch if Spell Storing has been used with this weapon as the focus.
Limitations: This spell can only be cast once on a single weapon.
Phys Rep: 150 word reference in spellbook, LARP Safe weapon

Description: The Mage can alter several minutes of a player’s in-character memory. Strength of Tier increase possible with Arcane Confluence.
Special: Duration: Permanent
Limitations: The Mage can alter X minutes equal to the Mage’s Tier. Cannot be used to change memory that occurred on a previous day.
Phys Rep: 140 words that include how the memory is being modified. Arcane focus.

Description: The Mage drains the heat from all around them to create a lashing, frozen storm. All types of mundane armor and shields are ineffective against Ice Storm.
Special: First strike brings a foe to a slow walk, Second strike freezes them in place for ten seconds, Third strike creates a mortalled, frozen body.
Limitations: If used with Spell Storing, the first 50 words can be stored but the remaining 90 must be spoken in order to convey the spell’s effects.
Phys Rep: 140 words in spellbook. Effects begin after 50 words and the Mage can move freely around the field while continuing to cast the spell, stopping briefly to state effects as the spell is in play.

Description: The Mage draws dark, necrotic energy to release upon their foes.  Necrotic Blast can also be used to destroy objects such as chests, gates, walls, siege engines and more. Destroys shields on strike.
Special: Damage: 4 Magic Necrotic damage to NPCs. Instant death to PCs regardless of armor.
Phys Rep: 80 word spell in spellbook, Arcane Focus. 6” minimum black spellball or alternatively character themed coreless black throwing weapons such as darts, knives, or axes.

Description: The Mage approaches the pinnacle of their necromantic arts as they are able to now animate a hoard of undead. The Mage may select to animate a dead creature as a Zombie (2HP, movement limited to walking) or a Skeleton (1HP, moves freely, ignores thrusts and arrows). Both attack with Necrotic Damage. Both take double damage from Holy damage. Both are dependent on orders from their master and can only follow the most basic of commands. In the absence of commands from their master, they attack the nearest creature until destroyed. When players regain life, they do not regain any memories of their actions while animated. Strength of Tier increase possible with Arcane Confluence.
Special: Duration: 10 minutes or until slain. If not slain within 10 minutes, the undead player may choose to remain an undead minion to the casting Mage for only as long as they wish.
Limitations: Players may decline to be animated. Upon taking this spell, a Mage may increase their Animated Dead to 1 in play per every Mage/Healer Tier.
Phys Rep: 100 word spell in spellbook, Arcane Focus. Skeleton mask or gray headband, Zombie mask or black headband

Description:
The Mage is able to send an NPC creature away. This can be used on regular NPCs and creatures brought into play via the Summon Creature spell.
Limitations: Requires coordination with the Game Officials. The Mage can only banish creatures of a lower tier than the Mage. Strength of Tier increase possible with Arcane Confluence. Cannot be used in conjunction with Spell Storing.
Special: Duration: When successfully cast, the target creature will move at best speed directly away from the caster.
Limitations: May be used 1x per day +1 per Mage Tier above Tier 7. Mage can only banish creatures of a lower tier than the mage. Cannot be used in conjunction with Spell Storing
Phys Rep: 150 word spell in spellbook, Arcane Focus

Description: The Mage draws dark energy that coalesces into a swirling ball of chaos, crackling with power. Bypasses all shields and armor. Disintegrate can also be used to destroy objects such as a gate.
Special: Damage: 8 Magic. Instant death to PCs regardless of armor.
Limitations: A disintegrated player can only be brought back via a Greater Power or the Resurrection spell.
Phys Rep: 140 word spell in spellbook, Arcane Focus. 6” minimum black spellball or alternatively character themed coreless black throwing weapons such as darts, knives, or axes.

Description: The Mage is able to locate any singular object that they have previously seen or held.
Limitations: Requires coordination with the Game Officials for the spell’s Vision. The Mage is immobile while casting. The Mage is unable to locate an object stored within an extra-dimension space.
Phys Rep: 200 word ceremony, Arcane Focus

Description: The Mage is able to instantly transport themselves and a number of allies to any one Hex. The spell has a 5% chance to fail where the Mage will engage in an encounter rolled separately by the GM on the Unit and Land Searches encounter table.
Limitations: Requires coordination with the Game Officials. The Mage may teleport themselves and a number of allies up to their Mage Tier.
Phys Rep: 200 words performed in a ceremony setting

Description:
The Mage is a Master of the Elements and can choose to imbue an entire battlefield with elemental effects.
Static Clouds: Players are subject to an array of continuous and unlimited bolts of lightning that deal 1 damage to struck players.
Icy Ground: Players can only move at half speed. If they attempt to run, they slip and fall.
Lava Plumes: Players are struck with balls of fire that deal 4 points of damage. The number of balls conjured is equal to the Mage’s Tier
Creeping Earth: If Players become stationary, they are rooted in place until another player touches them.
Limitations: Requires coordination with the Game Officials. If the Mage’s party is thwarted, the effect may not come to an end. The Mage must assist with the on-field battle effects and has permission to GM the spell effects.
Phys Rep: 200 word spell that may be cast prior to the encounter, Arcane Focus

Description: The Mage is able to bring all other sound to a halt in an area around them that expands to all who heard their booming call or noise. No sound can be made. No sound can be heard. All fall to an unnatural, deathly silence. Spells cannot be cast. Skills that require verbal components cannot be used.
Special:
Area: Effects all who heard the loud noise. This can be altered to cover a certain area if performed within a mod.
Duration: Until the end of the encounter, dismissed by the Mage, or the Mage becoming mortally wounded
Limitations: Requires coordination with the Game Officials. After the effect is completed, the Mage cannot cast spells for the remainder of the day and may also struggle to speak or make any noise at all.
Phys Rep: 10 words and a loud noise effect

Description: Player gains the ability to loot bodies left on the field. Using the Loot ability you gain in-game items carried by the lootee, including coins up to 2 additional silver per Tier (minimum 2 silver at Tier 0); one in-game item, potion, or scroll per tier; or one artifact carried by the looted.
Limitations: Players cannot Loot another player's personal items, including weapons, out of game items, or jewelry.
Phys Rep: Player holds hand over the location being looted and says “ I am searching this location” (the player being looted is NEVER physically touched.) The player being looted must reveal any items carried or hidden in the location being searched, except for objects protected by Tier 4 Conceal Item.

Description: Using this ability, Rogues can now see traps laid before them, check a Suspicious Location for a trap, or discern if an item, door, or container is trapped. They are able to discern the full location of the trap if it is an area trap, but not the potential consequences activating the trap could have, based on their Tier and knowledge of traps, until they attempt to interact with the trap, by reading the Trap Card.
Limitations: Each search is limited to a single item or area within a 10’ radius. Detect Trap allows the Rogue to understand whether something is a threat without setting off the trap.  However, the Rogue will have to interact with it to Bypass Trap, Destroy Trap, or Disarm Trap, taking a risk.
Phys Rep: Role play, 15 seconds. The player detecting traps must carefully look at an object, or search an area, and may then locate, but not read any ribbons, or cards placed on an item, or in the area searched to discern the Tier of the trap’s creator, and type of trap. That is revealed by further inspection.

Description: The Player learns how to finish a fallen enemy. A mortally wounded player can be engaged with to collaborate in a short scene that results in the full defeat of a target player.
Phys Rep: A 3-5 second engagement with a mortally wounded player for an epic style kill.

Description: Rogues gain the ability to safely use small to medium sized shields, up to 27” in diameter. Custom shields must be able to fit inside a 27” square. If a rogue receives further training in shield use to negate the size restriction through another tree, the larger shield interferes with rogue skills marked with the stealth tag.

Players learn the basic combat and safety rules and the use of all hand weapons and throwables. Additionally, Rogues may Dual Wield with approval from an organizer or Knight and Noble of the realm during Weapon’s Check. The only weapons this does not include are those found in the Advanced Weapon Proficiency (link) (Great Weapons and Polearms)

Players learn about the armor that they may wear and about its effective and safe use in play. A rogue’s starting max AP is 2. Metal Armor may interfere with some of the rogue skills, those skills are marked with a stealth tag.

Rogues find out early on that the best way to learn is by watching, and helping the best rogues learn that they can get further by working together. When faced with an obstacle that is beyond their capabilities they can utilize Cooperative Action with the help of other rogues to gain an advantage. The rogue that takes the action receives +1 to their effective tier for each rogue with Cooperative Action working together. In order for a Cooperative Action to be successful, the total tier must be greater than the tier of the lock,trap, or other obstacle in order to be successful in attempts to achieve their goal.It takes double the amount of time as normal to complete skills when done as a Cooperative Action.
Phys Rep: All rogues must be within touch distance obstacle, and engaged in role play.

Description: (stealth) The player is now able to pick locks of a strength equal to or less than their Rogue Tier. It takes 60 seconds uninterrupted to successfully pick a lock. Once picked, the lock is broken and may not be repaired.
Phys Rep: A skeleton key or lockpicking kit of a nature that suits their character.

Description: (stealth) After Detect Trap, Rogues may now choose to investigate further and read the trap card with the Bypass Trap ability. The player is now able to safely work around some traps after detecting them, temporarily bypassing their effects. When using this ability, the rogue is able to temporarily disable a trap, holding the mechanisms that would set it off in place in order to move an item, unlock and open a door or container, or pass safely over a trapped area. A player using this Rogue ability must have one part of their person in contact with the trapped item, container, or location at all times. Once they stop their control over the trap’s mechanisms, or leave the area, the trap is considered rearmed. The player may bypass a trap set by a Rogue equal to or lower than their Tier.
Phys Rep: The Rogue should carry a set of thieves' tools. After using Detect Trap, take out the tools and perform a 10 second RP. The player compares the Tier of the trap set on the item, container, or location to their Tier to determine outcome. If the trap is of an equal to or lower Tier than the Rogue’s it is safely bypassed.  If the trap is higher Tier, then the effects of the trap take place immediately.

Description: (stealth) The player can now scale walls and cliffs. This means during sieges, players can climb over walls in order to infiltrate the interior of castles or other buildings.
Limitations: Not all obstacles can be climbed for safety reasons. Characters wearing metal armor or overencumbered for their max AP may not benefit from Climb Walls, even if a rope is provided.
Phys Rep: In order for this skill to be put into effect, the player must simulate climbing and may then enter a structure or cross an obstacle in a safe location. A rope may be tied to the wall or location to allow others to follow. Those players must also simulate climbing.

Description: Players are taught the safety rules of archery at LARP Adventures and earn the use of bow and arrow in play.

(stealth) The rogue, adept in the art of sleight of hand, is able to pilfer coins or in-game items, such as potions and scrolls equal to roughly 2 silver per tier. Pickpocketing is a crime of opportunity, slipping into someone’s pouch while they are not looking, and oftentimes the loot received is random. The arbiters of the realm (organizers and leaders of the OOC rogue’s guild) have the final say to ensure Pickpocketing is always a fair, balanced, and fun part of play. Players cannot receive another player's personal items, including weapons, out of game items, or jewelry.  They must clip a clothespin from the waist up and neck down (hair/wigs are not a legal location) on a player without being detected. If they are detected, the pickpocket fails. If successful, when the clothespin is found the player being pickpocketed must locate a game organizer or merchant and return the clothespin and pay the appropriate amount of coin or relinquish an in-game item of equal value.
Limitations: Players may only use Pickpocket an amount of times per day equal to their tier, and can hold a matching number of clothespins at a time. Must seek an Organizer or participating Merchant to collect Pickpocketed items. Further information about stealing/pickpocketing can be found in Thievery in Osterra: A Comprehensive Guide
Phys Rep: A clothespin marked with a player’s symbol and tier.

Description: Rogues learn the ability to set simple traps on an item, door, or container that cause one wound to the nearest limb of a player attempting to open them, that disregards normal armor. Along with Poison Use, traps can be made to not only cause damage but also have other effects, see Tier 3 Create Poison.
Limitations: Players can only set 1 trap per Tier per event-day. Traps are limited to 1 per item, or container.
Phys Rep: The Rogue should carry a set of thieves' tools to RP. Setting a trap takes 30 seconds per Tier of the Trap created (may be incorporated into the actual physical setup of a trapped item or container).  Players use a card with the trap's effect as well as the Tier and character name, or Guild Mark of the player that set the trap. Trap cards for items and containers may be small and discreet, but should be easily discernible for other players. Props should be constructed in such a way that another player with Detect Trap should be able to discern easily if there is or is not a trap without gaining knowledge about the potential effect of the trap.

Description: This skill allows the Rogue to trap an area or location. These traps represent the ability to set snares, tripwires, and and pitfalls, as well as an understanding of how to disguise them. Rogues with Area Traps gain the ability to set “Suspicious Locations” These are areas that look suspicious upon inspection, even to the untrained eye, but only a Rogue can safely determine if they are truly trapped or a ruse.These traps can be used to ensnare/hold a player for a number of minutes equal to the Tier of the Rogue that set the trap in a location, or cause damage equal to the Tier of the Rogue to anyone in the area of effect that applies to a targeted hit location of the Rogue’s choosing.
Limitations: Players can only set 1 Area Trap per Tier per day. Area Traps are limited to 1 per 10’ area.
Phys Rep: Roughly the size of a sheet of paper, one side labeled “Suspicious Location” and the other side denoting if the area is safe or if it is trapped. If trapped, a description of the effect. The Suspicious Location marker must also include the Tier and character name, or Guild Mark of the player that set the trap  A black ribbon is used to denote the location of the trap in an area of up to 10’ in diameter. Suspicious Location markers should be easily discernible for other players.

Description: Your character may now handle basic poisons safely. Poison may be used on weapons, in traps, and on items like cups and plates. Refer to Create Basic Poison for details and effects. Applying poison to a vessel (weapon, ammunition, trap, object) takes 10 seconds per Tier of the Poison. Each poison is a single-use consumable. For weapons, poison effects are inflicted by dealing a wound, but it is not wasted if you hit an armored area. For ammunition, applied poison is harmlessly expended if it hits the ground. Once poison is applied, any vessel is poisoned until one of three things happen: discharge of the poison into a victim, death of the poisoner (for equipped weapons or ammunition), or end of event-day.
Limitations: Only 1 poison may be used on each item. Basic Poison Use can be countered by spells such as Cure Ailments or Heal Senses, depending on the nature of the poison. Organizers should be informed of a player's intent to use poison in play to facilitate role play and effects. You may not apply poison to others’ possessions who do not have Basic Poison Use, hoping to benefit them. Those without Basic Poison Use poison themselves within seconds, as they aren’t trained.
Phys Rep: A purple sticker or ribbon used to denote the in game consumable or item the poison is placed on.

Description: (stealth) Rogues use Waylay in order to rob, or seize an unsuspecting target player without killing them, it is an intercept or attack from ambush. The target of a Waylay strike is knocked unconscious for a maximum of 5 minutes or until released by the Rogue.
Limitations: Target must be surprised, cannot be aware of the Rogue’s presence/intention. Further damage immediately rouses the player from their state and are once again able to fight, run away, or take any other action provided no other impediments.
Phys Rep: Small club, mallet, or flail. The Rogue must attack by surprise, from behind, and proclaim “Waylay!” as well as declare what is happening to the unsuspecting victim while striking to communicate the non-lethal hit, that ignores normal armor.

Description: The player is now able to create locks in strength equal to their Tier level. They may also create keys that they can give to other characters.
Limitations: Each lock costs the player 2 silver to craft and takes 1 minute to make.
Phys Rep: RP and a  piece of black ribbon tied around the outside of a container or locked item. The ribbon must be denoted with the players tier, as well as their character name so it can be returned to them if necessary.

Description:
Your character may now create basic poisons, provided you pay for the reagents. Players may craft 2 poisons (plus an additional poison each Tier after Tier 3) per event. Poisons expire after three events. Exposure to the poison confers the following effect:
Maim: The injured limb cannot be used.  This poison remains in effect even if killed, between revivals. It may be removed by Cure Ailment. 
Combat Cue: “Can’t use arm” or similar.
Recurring: After 60 seconds, the target takes 1 damage to the affected limb per minute until cured by Cure Ailment. Once the target is mortally wounded, the poison resolves. 
Combat Cue: “One damage per minute!”
Sensory: Choose one sense: sight, hearing, or speaking. This poison prevents use of that sense until cured by Heal Senses, if applicable. Remains in effect even if killed. 
Combat Cue: “Blinded!” or similar.
Qualities of poisons: 
The Tier required to remove the poisons’ effects is the Tier of the Poison. 
Untreated or unless otherwise stated, effects last for 1 minute per Tier of poison. Some persist even after reviving.
Poisons are one-use consumables; once a wound is applied, the weapon is no longer poisoned.
Special: Sometimes in the heat of battle, target players might not understand combat cues.  Find safe ways to explain if possible, but if it doesn’t work, consider the poison unexpended.
Limitations: Poisons, in combat, are only effective when unarmored locations are struck, only affects a player if their hit points are impacted. Basic poisons cost 2 silver plus an additional 1 silver per tier of the poison, this coin is given to the Organizers to then know you have poisons crafted. You may not apply basic poisons to others’ possessions who do not have Poison Use, hoping to benefit them. Nothing physically should ever actually be put in someone else's food or beverage.
Phys Rep: A vial containing liquid with a tag or card with an explanation and the expiration date. When applied, a purple sticker or ribbon is used to denote the in-game consumable or item the poison is placed on. In combat, use a combat cue to explain.

Description: (stealth) Players who have learned the art of Backstab, know where and how to strike most effectively, at close quarters, in order to quickly incapacitate an opponent.  Using a dagger or short sword (up to 24”), a player with this skill may inflict wounds that ignore all normal armor, dealing an amount of damage up to the Rogue’s Tier when striking from behind and undetected. A backstab is considered a Coup de Grâce style attack, and fully defeats a foe if enough damage is dealt.
Limitations: Target must be surprised, cannot be aware of the Rogue’s presence/intention. Strike should be attempted to an unarmored area or a “weak point” in an enemies defense.
Phys Rep: Player must attack by surprise, from behind, and proclaim “Backstab!” as well as declare the number of points of damage inflicted while striking to communicate the hit.

Description: The Rogue now gains the ability through practice and a deep understanding of traps to completely destroy a trap without it going off or suffering any ill effects. The Rogue leaves the trap operationally ineffective, and it can never be reactivated, anyone can now pass through the area, or open an unlocked container, or door without hindrance. The trap setter is made aware their trap is destroyed by a Destroy Trap card left by the other Rogue.
Limitations: If the trap was created by a higher Tier Rogue, then the effects of the trap take place immediately.
Phys Rep: RP 15 seconds per tier of Trap to be destroyed. Destroy Trap card

Description: Players gain the ability to investigate an area and conclude what direction a specific target went. They are able to follow tracks that others cannot see and can conclude things such as party size, the creatures/characters physical state, and speed traveled. Additionally, a Rogue with this ability can allow for their party to re-engage with a previously failed land action during their next land action. The Rogue and their party may engage the new land action challenge as well as the one they previously failed, Tracking their target across the Lands of Osterra and possibly rectifying past failed land searches if successful.
Limitations: May be used 1x per day per Tier. Requires Game Official to be present.
Phys Rep: Players must spend 30-60 seconds in role play investigating an area, and seek out an organizer for information.

Description: Players can forge a number of documents that are identical to the ones they wish to create or copy. This could include signatures, identification, scrolls, letters, and whole books, given enough time, as well as many written things. The tier of the forgery is at maximum equal to the tier of the rogue. A player without forgery will believe the document is completely real, and only another player with a higher or equal Rogue tier to the tier of the forgery can identify it as a fake.
Limitations: Rogues can create 2 documents per Tier gained after learning this skill per event. Magic scrolls copied in this way are non magical and when read create no effects. A player of higher Tier with the Forgery skill may identify the forgery.
Phys Rep: A forged document that looks similar to the original, with the marking of the Rogue somewhere on the document and the tier of the forgery itself.

Description: Rogues learn how to quickly and effectively restrain an individual. A rogue can bind the limbs of their target to restrict their movement, or allow them to be easily transported.
Limitations: The opposing player must be held by Waylay, in a state of surrender, or already defeated. Players may decline to be bound, and players should never actually be tied up for any reason during game play. If a player refuses to be bound, they automatically suffer a “Coup de Grâce”.
Phys Rep: A reasonably sturdy rope at least 5 feet in length. To bind another player you must first ask them if they are ok with role playing being tied up. Then you must be able to role play for at least 10 seconds, handing the bound player the rope to safely wrap around a limb or to hold.

Description: The player has learned greatly of the underground market and has many contacts. The Rogue now gains the ability to steal from designated areas of Merchant Stalls. These areas are denoted with a specific fabric square to show a border of what items can be “stolen” and are labeled as “Special Items” in the merchant’s stall. They also now know how to advertise stolen quest items or in-game items to seem as though they were acquired legitimately, and can avoid suspicion when selling any items. They also receive a 25% off discount at all NPC shops and for specific services at Merchant’s Guild vendors in the realm. Fenced items may be sold to merchants or redeemed for coins from Game Officials.
Limitations: May be used 1x per day per Tier. Requires adjudication by Organizers, Rogue Leadership, or Merchants.
Phys Rep: Jeweler's loupe, small scale, or other appropriate appraisal tool. Requires 30 second minimum role play and then may seek out Game Officials to turn in items for payment. The Rogue receives additional clothespins that say “Fence” along with their symbol which are then placed on or near the object they intend to steal. These do not draw from the same Rogue’s pool as Pickpocket. No items should ever be physically removed from a merchant’s table by the Rogue.

Description: Your experience with poison allows you to use especially temperamental or dangerous ones.  The mechanics for your Basic Poison Use now apply to Monstrous Poisons as well. Refer to Create Monstrous Poison for details and effects.
Limitations: Only 1 poison may be used on each item. Can be countered by spells such as Cure Ailment or Heal Senses, depending on the nature of the poison. Organizers should be informed of a player's intent to use poison in play to facilitate role play and effects. You may not apply poison to others’ possessions who do not have Monstrous Poison Use, hoping to benefit them. It takes 1 minute per Tier of the poison to apply it safely.
Phys Rep: A purple sticker or ribbon used to denote the in game consumable or item the poison is placed on.

Description: You are the assistant everyone wants in the heist.  For Rogue skills you are assisting with as a Cooperative Action, you may add 2 to their effective Rogue tier instead of 1.

Rogues learn the ability to set more advanced traps that cause one wound of torso damage per Tier to the player attempting to move an item, or open a trapped door, or container: normal armor rules apply. Along with Poison Use, traps can be made to not only cause damage but also have other effects: see Tier 3 Create Poison.
Limitations: Players can only set 1 trap per Tier at a time. Traps are limited to 1 per container, or 1 per 10’ area. This does not add to the number of traps you can have in play; it just increases their effectiveness.
Phys Rep: RP, setting a trap takes 30 seconds per Tier: higher Tier traps are more complicated and deadly. Players use a card to denote the trap's effect as well as the Tier and character name of the player that set the trap in the container that has been trapped, or on a black ribbon and Suspicious Location card used to denote the location of the trap.

Description: (stealth) The Rogue now gains the ability to completely disarm a trap that they have detected. The rogue leaves the trap operationally ineffective and all players can now move an item, open an unlocked container, or pass through an Area Trap without hindrance thereafter. The player may disarm a trap set by a Rogue equal to or lower than their Tier. The trap setter is made aware their trap is disarmed by a Disarmed Trap card left by the Rogue. Or the trap may be rearmed and left in place. The Rogue may also disassemble each disarmed trap to temporarily add to their maximum traps per day.
Limitations: See Destroy Trap. Disassembled traps do not maintain their effects.  Additional traps are lost at the end of an event.
Phys Rep: Disarmed Trap card with character name or Guild mark and Tier, if left disarmed. RP 15 seconds per Tier of trap to be disarmed.

Description: The Rogue has learned how to effectively hide items on their person, and may conceal items from being Looted, Pickpocketed, or seen by other players.
Limitations: A concealed item must be able to roughly fit in a closed hand. 1 use per day and additional use for every 2 Tiers after 4th. After an item is revealed or the event day ends, another use must be expended to conceal the item again. Conceal Item may be used in tandem with reverse pocket to hide an item on another player, the player must be aware Out of Game they possess the item.

Description: You are not easily surprised by ambushes in environments you have mastered exploring.  Choose one hex type: Mountain, Plains, Sea/Coastal, Tundra, Blasted Lands, or Forests.  You cannot be surprised or ambushed during an exploration of a hex of this type, if you are in the adventuring party (rolling 1 on Affinity table).  Any damage or disadvantage associated with surprise at the beginning of the encounter is canceled out.

(stealth)  The rogue, now a master in the art of sleight of hand, is able to place in-game items, such as poisons, cursed items, or incriminating documents on other players. The items take immediate effect on the player and take effect or are noticed depending on the item placed on the opposing player.
Limitations: Rogues can only carry clothespins equal to their Tier, and utilize the same pool as the pickpocket ability
Phys Rep: The game mechanic is the same as the Pickpocket ability, the Rogue must seek out a Game Official and give them the items that are to be Reverse Pickpocketed, then a clothespin marked with the Rogue’s symbol and tier is placed surreptitiously on the unsuspecting player. When the clothes pin is found on the player they must seek out the Game Official, who then explains what has transpired and give the player the planted item. The item and any effects then come into play immediately.

Description: Through training and practice the Rogue has become a master of agility; they dodge hits with ease as they flee from combat. While running away from a fight, a Rogue with Quick Feet gains +2 floating hit points for 5 seconds.
Limitations: May be used three times per event.  This increases by one for every Tier above Tier 5.
Phys Rep: The player proclaims, “Quick Feet” and turns their back from the main combat and must take at least 3 steps away from the melee.

Description: Marrying locksmithing to trap-making, you’ve found a way to automate traps resetting.  Once per event-day, you may expend a Lock you have created via Locksmithing to instill a resetting quality in a Trap.  Each time this trap is sprung, it instantly resets, until the end of the event.  You gain one extra use of Clockwork Trap for every two Tiers above Tier 5.
The player is able to escape from all mundane means of binding them, traps and physical binding cannot restrict the rogue's escape.
Phys Rep: Role play, when players with the Slip Bonds ability are bound, they pull on the bindings as normal, but after 5 seconds they become completely free, and may take any game actions they wish.

Description: The Rogue becomes a master of disguise and is able to forge a whole new identity that they are directly able to convince all other characters of, even those connected to the character. They take on all aspects of the new form, but they do not gain any ability associated with the false character’s class or proclaimed tier.
Limitations: A player of a Higher Tier with Forge Persona may be able to detect the disguise. Cannot be used to portray a Player Character. At minimum, it takes the Rogue 5 minutes to take on a new disguise or return to their original form.
Phys Rep: The player must put together a disguise suitable to their false identity.

Description: (Stealth) The player can now hide in the shadows around them, whether in a bustling market, disorganized tavern basement, dungeon deep, the thralls of a forest, or anywhere else that a clear shadow casts over. They become undetectable to all mundane methods of detection as long as they are not moving and are crouched behind cover, or in an actual shadow.
Limitations: When the player moves out of their position, or engages in an offensive action, their Hide in Shadows is over and they are detectable.
Phys Rep: The player takes a crouching stance, if spotted they may respond silently with one held over their mouth, shaking their head side to side in a negative gesture to denote they are using their Hide In Shadows ability.

Description: With your charisma, strangers and beasts alike find you hard to hate. The player can now utilize their prowess in communication to calm the aggressive nature of moderately intelligent beasts and monsters. By using a combination of  verbal, and nonverbal communication, skilled rogues can calm a beast, monster, or even the common vagabond down to a less immediately aggressive state. When you roll for a random encounter’s disposition, you may increase the Affinity roll by 1 if not an ambush. Additionally, this skill may be attempted through roleplay to curry favor with NPCs outside of Land Actions, subject to Organizer oversight. Results may vary
Limitations: Requires attempts to Charm or sway disposition before combat begins.  Subject to discretion.

Description: You understand that the benefits of Osterra’s underworld requires discretion, and there will be hell to pay if you become an informant.  If Compel Truth, Speak with Dead, or any similar effect under your Tier is cast upon you, with a mind toward extracting information, you may resist its effects and can be fully immune to them if the rogue is of a higher tier.
Limitations: If the player asking questions is of a higher tier, the Rogue must answer if they fail in a coin flip, rock paper scissors, or similar game of chance.
Phys Rep: Rogue proclaiming they are “Not a snitch” and trying to skirt questions. RP required.

Description:
Your character adds new, potent, and dangerous recipes for poisons, distilled from monsters, having special effects.
Bone Naga: Inflict 3 additional damage.
Demon Blood: Target flies into a frenzy, attacking friend and foe.  This frenzy can be prematurely ended by taking a hit from a friendly character– snapping them out of it.  Combat Cue: “Frenzy until hit!”
Illithid Ichor: Target will be unable to recall events from one minute prior to the poisoning through the poison’s duration– they may only travel at walking speed and speak at a whisper as everything gets fuzzy. Combat Cue: “Walk and whisper!”
Due to the toxicity of the reagents, the minimum potency is Tier 3.
Special: In emergencies, Demon Blood and Illithid Ichor are diametric and can be administered to treat each others’ symptoms.
Limitations: Monstrous Poison reagents cost 4 silver plus an additional 1 silver per tier of the poison. Create Basic Poison and Create Monstrous Poison are part of the same count of per-event poison distillation.

Description: Traps are fast, but you are faster.  Once per event, you may avoid the direct consequences (damage, poison) of a sprung trap. You gain an additional use daily for every four Tiers above Tier 6.
Limitations: Resetting traps still reset– springing them does not always imply that you gain access. Indirect consequences, such as the trap triggering the room to fill with water, still happen.

Description: You are one with the shadows, whether you remain still or not.  When you use Hide in Shadows, you remain undetectable if you walk while crouching– so long as you are reasonably behind cover or in actual shadow.
Phys Rep: The player crouch-walks at a relatively slow speed with one finger held over their mouth. If seen, they shake their head side to side in a negative gesture to denote they are using Shadowstep and cannot be seen or heard.

Description: The player, trained in ranged combat arts, can now hit a bullseye shot that deals double damage to the player struck with any ranged weapon.
Limitations: Can only be used twice per day with +1 added after each Rogue Tier past 6th.
Phys Rep: The player calls out “Bullseye!” at their target, and must strike them with an arrow or other ranged weapon.

Description: Once per event-day, one arrow you fire inflicts Waylay, even if the mark is not surprised.  This effect lasts for 10 seconds or until damaged.  The immobilization is able to be sustained indefinitely if the archer moves within reach of the mark and uses Waylay.  You gain an additional event-day use for every two Tiers above Tier 7.
Phys Rep: The player calls out “Waylay 10 seconds” at their target, and must strike them with an arrow.
Prerequisite: Archery AND Waylay AND Bullseye Shot

Description: You safeguard your bag or carried possessions with a trained creature or small trap.  Once per event-day, you may negate one pickpocket attempt, when a Pickpocket receives their clothespin back, they instead receive 1 point of damage through armor.
Phys Rep: A black ribbon on your belt or pouch, expend one trap use.  Alternatively, for ranger-types, a representation of an animal on your person instead.  A note that indicates that the thief has taken 1 wound to the limb they pickpocketed with, when returning a clothespin.

Description: In your capable hands, the surprise of a quick small blade can do as much damage as a greatsword. Any dagger or short sword under 20 inches you wield, used in melee, deals +1 damage on its first hit in an encounter.
Phys Rep: A black ribbon on the weapon.

Description: Through deft, acrobatic movement, you can close the distance with your foes.  When you use Quick Feet, you may instead move any direction, even toward the fight, taking at least three steps and gaining the floating hit points for five seconds.

You have mastered one basic poison, making it your signature.  When creating a specific type of potion, you may optionally perfect it.  Choose one type:
Maim: Only one limb may be used.  The creator chooses the limb. Combat Cue: “Use right arm only!” or similar.
Recurring: Once the target is mortally wounded, the poison goes dormant and returns if a character is stabilized OR revives after death.
Sensory: The target cannot see, hear, or speak. Combat Cue: “Cannot see, hear, or speak.”
Perfected poisons cost double to create.
Special: You may take this skill multiple times. For each time taken, choose another poison type you can perfect.
Limitations: See Create Basic Poison. If you choose to perfect a created poison in this manner, its minimum Tier must be Tier 7.
Phys Rep: See Create Basic Poison.

Description:
You have mastered one basic poison, making it your signature.  When creating a specific type of potion, you may optionally perfect it.  Choose one type:
Maim: Only one limb may be used.  The creator chooses the limb. Combat Cue: “Use right arm only!” or similar.
Recurring: Once the target is mortally wounded, the poison goes dormant and returns if a character is stabilized OR revives after death.
Sensory: The target cannot see, hear, or speak. Combat Cue: “Cannot see, hear, or speak.”
Perfected poisons cost double to create.
Special: You may take this skill multiple times. For each time taken, choose another poison type you can perfect.
Limitations: See Create Basic Poison. If you choose to perfect a created poison in this manner, its minimum Tier must be Tier 7.
Phys Rep: See Create Basic Poison.

You have mastered one basic poison, making it your signature.  When creating a specific type of potion, you may optionally perfect it.  Choose one type:
Maim: Only one limb may be used.  The creator chooses the limb. Combat Cue: “Use right arm only!” or similar.
Recurring: Once the target is mortally wounded, the poison goes dormant and returns if a character is stabilized OR revives after death.
Sensory: The target cannot see, hear, or speak. Combat Cue: “Cannot see, hear, or speak.”
Perfected poisons cost double to create.
Special: You may take this skill multiple times. For each time taken, choose another poison type you can perfect.
Limitations: See Create Basic Poison. If you choose to perfect a created poison in this manner, its minimum Tier must be Tier 7.
Phys Rep: See Create Basic Poison.

Description:
Through their Lecture, the Scholar is able to explain how to temporarily expand one’s senses, much like in the grounding rituals performed by Oona Cardot.  When spending a Skill Point to take this Skill, the Scholar must select one of the following Skills: [Detect Trap], [Sense Holy/Cursed] or [Sense Arcana].  
This skill may be taken more than once.
Those who attend the Lecture are able to use the chosen skill once (or once more) that Event Day, regardless of prerequisite skills.
Limitations: Requirement: Lecture (30 seconds), Finding

Description:
Through intense study, the Scholar is able to improve some talent in regards to their Main Path.  They are now able to permanently use that skill once more per day.
This Skill can be taken once per Scholar Tier.  It cannot be applied to the same Main Path Skill more than once, and cannot be applied to a Main Path Skill above the Scholar’s Scholar Tier.
Cross-trained Skills are counted as the Tier at which they can be cross-trained.
Special: The Scholar does not need to have the base Main Parth Skill they are conveying.
Limitations: Requirement: Treatise

Description: By expending a use of a Lecture, the Scholar may become a participant in another Scholar’s Lecture without counting towards their participant total.

With the support of literacy efforts in Osterra, the Scholar can help Lecture attendees understand runic texts.
Lecture attendees are able to use the skill [Read/Write Arcana] in order to cast one scroll. The effect lasts for the entire event-day, until the character is mortally wounded, or until the first instance of a character casting a spell while under the effect of the lecture.
Limitations: Requirement: Finding, Lecture (30 seconds)

Description:
By engaging in intellectual debate, the Scholar is able to apply the effects of another Scholar’s Lecture, as if they had given it themself.
Using the use of their Lecture, a Scholar may interrupt another Scholar giving a Lecture, inform them of their intent to debate by stating the word “Disputation,” and choose a number of additional Lecture Participants up to their Scholar Tier. The Scholars must roleplay a scene lasting an additional minute per Scholar using [Disputation] debating or discussing the topic of the original Scholar’s Lecture.  When the debate is complete, Participants chosen by all Scholars in the Lecture receive the effect of the original Scholar’s Lecture.
Special: The Scholar need not know the Skill the original Scholar is using.  More than one Scholar may use [Disputation] on the same Lecture. A Scholar using [Disputation] may be a Participant in the original Scholar’s Lecture.

Description:
Due to the Scholar’s work, such as King Nézmear’s work with monster parts, they have gained resistance to some poisons. Upon taking this Skill, the Scholar must choose a type of Poison. The Scholar is immune to this type of Poison, as long as the Poison’s level is less than or equal to half of their Scholar Tier, rounded down.
A Scholar may take this Skill multiple times, choosing a different Poison each time.
Limitations: Requirements: Treatise

Description:
Through their studies, a Scholar may change the damage type of the weapons of their allies.
Upon taking this Skill, choose a damage type.  A Scholar may perform a Lecture that changes the damage type of one weapon, up to the maximum of the number of allowable Participants in a Lecture for the Scholar’s Tier to that damage type for the rest of the event-day or until the wielder’s death. This damage type change overwrites previously applied damage type changes for the duration of [Invoke Element]’s effect, but does not affect any bonus damage conveyed.
Special: Transferring the weapon to another Character negates the effect of the Skill.
Limitations:
Requirement: Finding, Lecture (30 seconds)
Cannot be applied to thrown weapons.
Phys Rep: The damage type must be marked with a silver ribbon tied to the weapon. The Participant must call the damage type when performing hits.

Description: Through a Lecture, a Scholar may restore one use of a chosen Skill possessed by all of the participants of that Lecture.  The Skill chosen must be at or below the Scholar’s Scholar Tier.
Limitations:
Requirement: Finding, Lecture (30 seconds)
The Skill must have limited uses per day as stated in the text, and not specifically limited by a meta currency (i.e. Mana Points).  It does not affect Skills such as [Holy Relic], or [Scrolls and Potions]

Description:
Through intense study, the Scholar is able to improve some talent in regards to their Main Path.  They are now able to permanently use that skill once more per day.
This Skill can be taken once per Scholar Tier.  It cannot be applied to the same Main Path Skill more than once, and cannot be applied to a Main Path Skill above the Scholar’s Scholar Tier.
Cross-trained Skills are counted as the Tier at which they can be cross-trained.
Once per Season, a Scholar may write a new Treatise that grants one extra Skill Point to a Character (which may include oneself) for an event they are both attending.
Special: This extra Skill Point can be applied to any Character. The recipient of the Skill Point may not Peer Review the relevant Treatise.  This Skill may have the same recipient multiple times.
Limitations: Requirement: Treatise

Description: By writing a Treatise and paying the equivalent of 3 Gold or a Tier 3 Gem to the Merchant’s Guild at the beginning of a Season, a Scholar may allow a single Merchant to take an additional Perk (whose requirements the shop meets) that season.
Limitations: Requirement: Treatise, equivalent of 3 Gold or a Tier 3 Gem

Description:
Through their Lecture, a Scholar is able to explain ways to improve the efficiency of an Artificer’s practice.
Following the Lecture, reduce the gem cost of activating an Artificer Object by 1 tier (this gem can be no larger than your Scholar Tier) for a single activation.
Limitations: Requirement: Lecture (30 seconds), Finding

Description:
Through their Lecture and particular knowledge, a Scholar is able to assist a Bard’s Performance.
The Scholar may perform a collaborative Lecture with a Bard who has just finished a Performance, allowing the Scholar to perform the “Echo” effect once, without being a Milestone 2 Bard.
Special: Findings could, for instance, address the way in which one would use their particular knowledge to learn from the Bard, rather than knowledge on a particular subject the Bard is performing.
Limitations: Requirement: Lecture (30 seconds), Finding

Description:
Through intense study, the Scholar is able to improve some talent in regards to their Main Path.  They are now able to permanently use that skill once more per day.
This Skill can be taken once per Scholar Tier.  It cannot be applied to the same Main Path Skill more than once, and cannot be applied to a Main Path Skill above the Scholar’s Scholar Tier.
Cross-trained Skills are counted as the Tier at which they can be cross-trained.

By performing a Lecture, the Scholar can grant Participants the ability to deal an additional +1 damage for the rest of the event-day or until death.  
A Scholar may perform a Lecture that grants +1 damage to one weapon, up to the maximum of the number of allowable Participants in a Lecture for the Scholar’s Tier to that damage type for the rest of the event-day or until the wielder’s death.
Multiple instances of [Thesis Offense] cannot be stacked, and cannot be stacked with other sources of additional damage, such as [Enchant Weapon] or [Holy Relic]. It may stack with effects that change the weapon’s damage type, but not its modifier.
Special: Transferring the weapon to another Character negates the effect of the Skill.
Limitations:
Requirement: Lecture (30 seconds), Finding
Cannot be applied to thrown weapons.
Phys Rep: Brown ribbon tied around weapon

Description:
The Scholar is sometimes able to gain insights from their own Lectures.
When performing a Lecture, the Scholar may be counted as a participant of their own Lecture.

Through intensive study into their own field, the Scholar gains the ability to apply their knowledge to aspects of stewardship and statecraft, or other ways of contributing to a nation’s resources.
Once per Season, a Scholar may write a Treatise choosing a Land Game Hex. This Hex now produces additional resources for four Harvests.
	Wood/Food/Stone: Add +2 additional Resources.
	Ore/Gold/Silver: Add +2 to the dice roll when determining Resources.
The Scholar may pay the equivalent of 10 Gold in either Coin or Gems in order to use this Skill additional times each within a Season.
Special: A Hex may not be affected more than once.
Limitations:
Requirements: Treatise
One need not write Treatises for their own Faction.

Through intense study, the Scholar is able to improve some talent in regards to their Main Path.  They are now able to permanently use that skill once more per day.
This Skill can be taken once per Scholar Tier.  It cannot be applied to the same Main Path Skill more than once, and cannot be applied to a Main Path Skill above the Scholar’s Scholar Tier.
Cross-trained Skills are counted as the Tier at which they can be cross-trained.

There comes a time in a Scholar’s life where they must visit the Library of Osterra to make progress on their studies.
If a Scholar has missed an event, they may write a Treatise and pay the equivalent of 3 Gold or a Tier 3 Gem.  They may only gain a maximum of 1 Skill Point per event this way, regardless of event type.
The Skill Point is gained upon successful Peer Review.
Limitations: Requirements: Treatise, equivalent of Tier 3 Gem or a 3 Gold

Description:
The Scholar has become so practiced and efficient at lecturing, that they have found the means to best reach their participants.
The Scholar is able to include a participant in a Lecture that is already under the effect of a different Lecture.  The abilities apply simultaneously.

Through some means, whether it be an herbal concoction, inspiring words, or otherwise, the Scholar can enable others to push past their limits in a combat situation.
The Participants of the Lecture are granted the ability to use [Mighty Blow] once (or once more) during one encounter during the effect duration.  Once this use is expended, each of the arms of the Participant are disabled until healed by any means that would restore any hit points to the limb, unless the Participant possesses the Skill [Mighty Blow].
Effect Duration: Event-day
Limitations: Requirements: Finding, Lecture (30 seconds)

Description:
Through building rapport with their Organization (Faction, Interfaction Organization, etc), the Scholar can more effectively reach them with their Lecture.
A Scholar may declare an Organization and add up to a number of Participants up to their Scholar Tier from their Organization to their Lecture without counting them towards their total number of Participants.
Players learn the basic combat safety rules, and the use of hand weapons, and throwables.
Players learn about the armor that they wear and about its effective and safe use in play. A Warriors starting maximum Armor Point Total is 3.
The Player learns how to finish a fallen enemy. A mortally wounded player can be engaged with to collaborate in a short scene that results in the full defeat of a target player.
Players learn the art of Shield Control and may use shields in combat.
Study and become proficient in the use of Great weapons (Weapons over 5 and a half feet in length, or heavier than average LARP weapons), polearms, and dual wielding.
Players are taught the safety rules of archery at LARP Adventures and earn the use of bow and arrow in play.
Repairs a single hit location of non-metal armors at one armor point for every 10 seconds.
Phys Rep: Repair Kit and rp of repair (15 Seconds)

Description: Repairs normal shield for use.
Phys Rep: Repair Kit and rp of repair (15 Seconds)

Description: A warrior, or group of warriors working in collaboration can interact with a magical construct, affect, or item to temporarily deactivate it and interact with the object, area, or item freely. The amount of warriors needed is equal to the tier of the casted effect.
Limitations: Each warrior participating must have Warrior’s Will. Each warrior counts as one Tier towards the deactivation of the magical construct or effect.When working in unison the magical construct will only be deactivated for 10 seconds per tier of the highest tier Warrior that participated. Some magical constructs put into play by GMs may be unaffected or impossible to bypass.
Phys Rep: 15 seconds RP for each tier of the magical construct/effect. Warriors must be unarmed to attempt to out-will the enchantment or effect

Description: The warrior may now create a number of minor repair kits equal to half their tier rounded up per event. A minor repair kit can be used to instantly repair one hit location of AP 2 or lower armor or shields.
Limitations: Repair Kits expire after 3 months of being in play
Phys Rep: A small box with LARP safe repair implements inside. Warrior should also have access to a reference sheet with creation date and number of uses.

Description: The Player has gained experience and is learning how to best wear and fight in their armor. They can now add 1 to maximum AP. Typically done by layering armor, or upgrading material.
Repairs a single hit location of metal armors at one armor point every 10 seconds.
Phys Rep: Repair Kit and rp of repair (30 Seconds)

Description: Repairs normal weapon for use, for each point of damage the weapon deals, 15 seconds are needed for repair.
Phys Rep: Repair Kit and rp of repair (30 Seconds)

Description: The Warrior, now self-assured and well trained, can strike fear into the heart of a single NPC of an equal or lower tier once per event. The fear effect causes its target to turn and run the opposite direction for 5 seconds, or to wither and not be able to engage in combat.
Limitations: NPC must be sentient to able to be threatened
Phys Rep: Direct eye contact from within striking distance, and an assertive dialogue that specifically mentions “Fear”

Description: Character has built up endurance to pain and abuse and is hard to stop. The player gets one additional hit per hit location.
Limitations: Only effective for warriors wearing up to two Armor Points of physical armor per hit location, to a maximum of 3 Armor Points. Once a hit is sustained to a legal hit location, a minor heal can recover one hit point to that location. A Major Heal recovers two hit points. Upon death, no further healing or Roleplay is needed to recover Hardiness points. Effects that damage Hit Points or change them in anyway also alter Hardiness.
Phys Rep: Brown Belt Favor with a single stroke

Description: The player, already skilled in making repairs to armor and weapons, can now repair mundane structures and siege equipment. Every 15 seconds of Roleplay is one point restored to the structure.
Phys Rep: A hammer, shovel, or other “field repair” instrument.

Description: The Player possesses unyielding bravery, and becomes immune to fear, and resistant to other mind altering effects. If a creature or player causes fear, or attempts to alter the mind of the warrior, the player with Iron Will can ignore the effect. Iron Will is not effective against the forces of corruption.
Limitations: Only effective against effects of an equal or lower tier to the Warrior

Description: The warrior may now create a number of major repair kits equal to half their tier rounded up per event.  A major repair kit can be used to instantly repair one hit location of AP 3 or lower armor or weapons and shields.
Limitations: Repair Kits expire after 3 months of being in play
Phys Rep: A small box with LARP safe repair implements inside. Marked with date of creation

Description: May repair any item with only the things at hand. May be used on armor, weapons, and any non magical items or mechanisms.
Phys Rep: Usage of an available item as a stand in for a logical repair prop as needed in a situation. This could be: spare rope to fix a ship, the back of a sturdy weapon to repair armor, a coin to assist in repairing a broken chest, etc.
Prerequisite: Metal Armor Repair AND Shield Repair

Description: The player has gained notoriety for good or ill, a player with Renown should announce to the realm what it is they wish to be renowned for, so that their name is known far and wide. In negotiations a player with renown should be given special considerations, if a Renowned player is included in a land search, you may deduct 25% from the normal cost. (non-cumulative)

The character has developed the ability to gather and focus their strength into a powerful attack, a player with Mighty Blow does double damage with a single attack, a player using this ability with a two-handed strike, also gains the ability to destroy shields with this attack.
Limitations: May only be used once per combat at Tier 4, and one additional time per combat for every two tiers after 4th, up to a maximum of half the Players Tier per adventure day (rounded up).
Phys Rep: Role play and must include a declaration by the player that the strike is a Mighty Blow.

Description: Immense toughness allows the warrior a final blow after they have been mortally wounded in combat. A player with Last Strike may swing their weapon one final time at an opponent attempting to perform a finishing “Coup de Grâce” move before succumbing to their injuries and falling in battle.
Limitations: May only be used once per combat. Can only be used when a “Coup De Gras” is attempted.
Phys Rep: Role play and must include a declaration by the player that the strike is their Last Strike.

Description: The warrior’s ability is now well known, and can inflict fear on a single Player Character of a lower tier once per event. The fear effect causes a player to turn and run the opposite direction for 5 seconds or to wither and not be able to engage in combat.
Limitations: This skill may not be used on the same player twice in a row.
Phys Rep: Direct eye contact from within striking distance and an assertive dialogue that specifically mentions “Fear”

Description: Character has continued to build up endurance to pain and abuse and is even harder to stop. The Player gets two additional hits per hit location.
Limitations: Only effective for warriors wearing up to two Armor Points of physical armor per hit location, to a maximum of 4 Armor Points. Once a hit is sustained to a legal hit location, a minor heal can recover one hit point to that location. A Major Heal recovers two hit points. Upon death, no further healing or Roleplay is needed to recover Hardiness points. Affects that damage Hit Points or change them in anyway also alter Hardiness.
Phys Rep: Brown Belt Favor with two strokes

Description: Through extensive time in Combat, the warrior now gains an understanding in how to maximize the effectiveness of their armor, including the ability to layer armor extensively. This skill raises a character's maximum AP by 1.  A Warrior now can combine armor layers to reach a maximum AP of 5.
Phys Rep: A field encompassing shout, battle cry, horn blast, or other implement to cause noise and garner attention of allies, that lasts a minimum of 5 seconds.

Description: The player possesses the unrelenting bravery of Iron Will and is able to share their resistance to fear, and other mind altering effects. All allied players that can hear the Rallying Cry are also immune to fear, and resistant to mind altering based effects, any effects in play at the time the Rallying Cry is made are lifted or subside.

hrough sheer will or years of training the warrior has trained their mind to briefly ignore its physical limitations. The player becomes rage incarnate and may take 5 hits from any weapon regardless of their current Armor Points or injuries after Brutal Rage is invoked. The Warrior may continue to fight in this way until all hits are expended or 60 seconds have passed, at which point they die, regardless of damage incurred.
Limitations: May only be used once per combat, up to a maximum of 3 times per adventure day.
Phys Rep: Role play, and must include a declaration by the player that they are entering their Brutal Rage.

Description: The character has been wronged in the past and holds enmity against a certain creature (typically a specific type of Monster) and swears a Blood Oath against them, usually one that marauds their homeland or done them some great injustice. Typical enemies include giants, orcs, lizard men, trolls, ect. The player gains double damage versus their declared mortal enemies.
Limitations: Role play, a character that has declared a Blood Oath will actively seek out their enemy in combat in preference to all other foes, unless someone else presents a much greater danger. It is difficult for them to hide their hatred and it is only with great difficulty that they can encounter creatures that they have sworn a Blood Oath against without attacking them.
Phys Rep: A scroll of the Blood Oath created by the player that declares their mortal enemy.

Description:
The player already capable of impromptu repair is now trained in the art of combat engineering, having shown an aptitude to repair and build under combat conditions, the player amasses a kit of tools that allows them to half the time of repairs and gives them the ability to create simple offensive and defensive structures in the field. Structures appear as quickly as they can be brought to the field and may include the following:

Barricades: The player can construct up to 2 barricades + 1 for every Tier passed 6. Barricades may be up to 5’ feet wide and up to 2’ feet deep. They act as shields in reference to being destroyed and have 2 structural damage points at Tier 6, and +1 structural damage point for each Tier after.  

Trench: The trench is a 5x10 foot area that players passing through must go on their knees. 

Watchpost: The Player can construct up to 2 at a time watch posts that a single player can stand on. The watchpost is a single “fenced in” 5x5 block raised from the ground no more than 3 feet with only a single “entrance point”, the location of which is denoted by a lack of fence on the 5x5 block. Players on the watchpost cannot be engaged in melee combat unless from this entrance point. If a player falls from the watchpost by going off a point that is not the entryway or if the watchpost is destroyed, they are rendered unconscious. Watchposts act as shields in reference to being destroyed.

Battering Ram: The warrior may create a battering ram that can destroy normal doors and gates. A battering ram will do 1 structural point of damage per person operating it.
Phys Rep:
Barricades may be improvised with a pile of relatively safe brush or debris scavenged from surroundings, or prefabricated and put in place, alternatively the area may be marked with a rope, it must have a note attached that clearly marks it as a BARRICADE, and its structural points along with the makers mark and Tier.

Trench: Represented with an outline of field paint, foam, or black fabric.

Watchtower: A maximum of a 5x5 area roped off as a structure, with at least one clearly marked entrance.

Battering Ram: Battering rams can be made in the field, but should be made LARP safe (no sharp protrusions, or splintered ends), and must be at least 2’ long per person using the battering ram.

Description: The Warrior may now select a single element (Fire, Ice, Lightning, Necrotic) to specifically be resistant towards, taking only half damage from that source.
Phys Rep: A sigil of the chosen element somewhere clearly denoted on the warrior.

Description: Once per event, the player can decide to re-roll a land search action, or any other encounter table roll. They may then choose which dice result they wish to use. This can be utilized for the NPC type, enemy NPC amount, or other NPC disposition.

Before a battle begins the warrior can place their standard as a rallying point for their fellow battlemates. Players within 30 ft of the banner are immune to fear or other mind altering effects as long as the banner stands. Additionally, mortalled players who are able to crawl back and touch the banner may return to combat with a single Hit Point, but limbs are not healed or armor fixed. Further healing can bring them back to full strength.
Phys Rep: Roleplay and placing a physical banner with a distinct player’s or faction’s emblem in the ground, or holding it. The spot where the banner is to be placed may be pre-set.

Description: A warrior may choose a specific weapon that they excel in, and a specific form they may take on the field of battle to deal an additional point of damage while firmly in that form. The form must be custom to the warrior, but can share similarities with traditional fighting stances or other fictional portrayals.
Limitations: The Warrior can only take the stance once per day, and may only wield the specific weapons and armor their stance allows.
Phys Rep: A clear declaration of the stance they are taking, and a difference in form from their typical fighting style.

Description: The warrior’s shield is made more resilient by careful reinforcement, and the experience of the warrior has taught them how to deflect devastating blows more effectively. Negates 1 instance of any shield breaking effect. . One additional shield breaking effect can be negated for every two tiers beyond 6.
Limitations: Only works for the warrior with the skill. To restore break resistant effects, shield repairs must be performed
Phys Rep: Silver ribbon tied to shield at minimum, but, modifications to the shield such as representations of metal bands, reinforcement, reskinning the shield, etc are highly encouraged

Description: A warrior, with an imbued weapon of some type, can now deal damage to a magical construct, affect, or item. This may include wards, sanctified locations, and magical items. The hit points of the magical construct is equal to the casters tier. All arcane structures/items explode when destroyed, pushing players back 10 feet away from the structure/item and potentially destroying the weapon used or injuring those around the blast. (at organizer discretion).
Limitations: Weapon must be imbued with some effect

Description: After completing a “Coup de Grâce” style finishing move, all wounds on the warrior are temporarily healed to full. Does not repair armor, restore hardiness, or reactivate floating hits. The effect ends after combat and the Warrior collapses and is considered Mortally Wounded.
Limitations: After each “Coup De Gras” style kill, the warrior approaches closer to a frenzied state. After an amount equal to half their tier (rounded down), they no longer can distinguish friend from foe until they are slain and are considered frenzied.
Phys Rep: A finishing move that is about 2-3 seconds, along with a battle roar or other similar RP that lasts an additional 2-3 seconds.

Description: The Warrior’s prowess on the battlefield is now so known, that enemies often turn to flee before combat begins. Once per event, the Warrior may now inflict fear upon entire NPC groups to force them to turn and run the opposite direction for 5 seconds, or to wither and not be able to engage in combat.
Limitations: NPCs must be sentient, Leader of NPCs must be of a lower tier.
Phys Rep: A mighty shout, horn blast, or other signifier, followed by a proclamation including the name of the specific target or NPC group, that contains the word “fear”, and the name of the Warrior invoking the ability

Description: The Warrior may now take all damage in a hit pool fashion. All damage is dealt to a base of 6 Hit Points, with additional hit points added for their lowest AP legal hit location or maximum Hardiness Points, as well as typical means of adding floating hits (arcane armor, head/eye protection, etc.) The warrior no longer loses limbs during combat, and magic is dealt directly to their hit pool.
Phys Rep: A sigil of the chosen beast somewhere clearly denoted on the warrior.
